description: From Middle English conservatour, from Anglo-Norman conservatour, from Latin cōnservātor (“one who conserves”), agent noun from cōnservō (“I preserve”).

entries.meaning: One who conserves, preserves or protects something.
examples: Chlouveraki, a tenacious archaeological conservator, has salvaged antiquities all over the Middle East.

entries.meaning: (law) A person appointed by a court to manage the affairs of another; similar to a guardian but with some powers of a trustee.
examples: The Governor [of Missouri] is  […]  the conservator of the peace

entries.meaning: An officer in charge of preserving the public peace, such as a justice or sheriff.
(Roman Catholicism) A judge delegated by the pope to defend certain privileged classes of persons from manifest or notorious injury or violence, without recourse to a judicial process.
A professional who works on the conservation and restoration of objects, particularly artistic objects.
